awd_titl_txt: RUI: Structure, function and evolutionary history of beta-amylase2 (BAM2) in plants
awd_abstract_narration:
Starch is an important carbon- and energy-storage compound in plants and it has widespread use in industry and as part of the human diet. With this project the researchers aim to better understand the structure and function of a plant enzyme that they suspect plays and unusual role in starch metabolism. Potential long-term benefits of the research include modified crops that contain starch with properties suitable for improved food and industrial applications. In some plants this enzyme is encoded by a complex gene, the understanding of which could shed light on how genes evolve. The research will be carried out at a predominantly undergraduate institution and involve at least 12 undergraduates helping prepare them for graduate school and careers in science. The students will be involved in all aspects of the work. In addition, the project will support a postdoctoral scholar that will obtain valuable teaching experience in lectures and laboratories of introductory and advanced courses, as well as bringing valuable intellectual and technical assets to the lab. Most importantly, they will be able to develop undergraduate research mentoring skills and acquire practical advice for building a successful career at a predominantly undergraduate institution.

Starch is a complex polymer of glucose composed mostly of amylopectin, a highly branched molecule with layers of short chains that are 12-15 glucose units long. In green leaves starch accumulates during the day and is broken down at night so that the leaf can continue to export energy to the entire plant even when photosynthesis is not active. One of the key enzymes known to play an important role in starch degradation is beta-amylase, which hydrolyzes the disaccharide maltose from the ends of amylopectin. The researchers recently discovered that one of the beta-amylases in Arabidopsis called BAM2 is unlike all of the other characterized BAMs in that it is a tetramer, requires K+ for activity, possesses a secondary starch-binding site, and has sigmoidal kinetics. Based on these properties the researchers developed a hypothesis that BAM2 plays a role in starch synthesis as a trimming enzyme to ensure that the short amylopectin chains are of the proper length. To test this hypothesis, they will investigate the catalytic and starch-binding properties of the wildtype and mutant enzymes in detail. In addition, the function of the enzyme will be tested by characterizing the structure of starch isolated from wildtype and mutant plants lacking BAM2. The researchers will also investigate the localization and properties of the BAM2-like protein in rice plants that appears to be part of a longer BAM7 gene with two putative transcriptional start sites. Understanding the role of BAM2 in starch metabolism could have a significant impact on biotechnological efforts to enhance starch yield in crops. The experiments described here may shed light on how starch binding to an allosteric surface of BAM2 influences its catalytic activity. The work may also reveal how novel genes can be generated by fusion events and how they can evolve through duplication and neofunctionalization.

por.por_cntn:
Starch is a polymer of sugar that plants make to store energy for later use. In leaves starch accumulates during the day and is broken down at night when photosynthesis is not active. This way leaves can export sugar to the non-photosynthetic parts of plants day and night.  Plants also store starch in seeds and tubers for long term storage to be used as fuel for establishing the plant for the next year. Starch degradation requires many different proteins, one of which is beta-amylase or BAM. The model plant Arabidopsis thaliana contains nine BAM genes, six of encode proteins targeted to plastids, which are the site of photosynthesis and starch storage. This project focused on the structure, function and evolution of one of these BAMs called BAM2 which is found in all plants. We discovered that BAM2 is different than other beta-amylases in its structure and properties, suggesting that it might also have an unusual function in starch metabolism.

To investigate the function of a protein, two complementary approaches are usually taken – purifying the protein to characterize its specific properties and examining the properties of a mutant of the organism lacking just that protein. We purified BAM2 and found that it can act on a wide range of substrates including small maltodextrins. One of the unusual properties of BAM2 is that it requires K+ for activity. Using several techniques to monitor the structure and stability of proteins, we discovered that K+ allows BAM2 to form active conformations more easily but it also prevents the protein from denaturing. Our results point out the importance of measuring enzyme activity under physiologically relevant conditions.

BAM2 is widely expressed in plant tissues, which doesn’t point to a specific function, but suggests that its function may be widespread and thus potentially important.  One specific tissue in which BAM2 is expressed is one that also allows researchers to easily learn about its function and that is root caps. Root caps not only protect the root meristem from being damaged as the root grows through soil, but it also is the site where the direction of gravity is perceived by roots. Starch granules, being denser than water, fall to the bottom of root cap cells and thus determine to direction of gravity.  Examination of the root caps in mutants lacking BAM2 revealed that starch granules were larger and less abundant than in wild type root cells. This observation reminded us of starch granules in other mutants defective in starch granule initiation, some of which also have higher levels of maltodextrins that are necessary for initiating starch granules. This, along with the activity of BAM2 on maltodextrins suggests that BAM2 may play a role in regulating the initiation of starch granule formation. 

The model plant Arabidopsis thaliana contains BAM2 encoding a plastid-targeted enzyme, and a closely related BAM7 encoding a larger, nuclear targeted protein that binds to DNA and regulates gene expression but has no catalytic activity. We noticed that in corn and some other related plants, there was a single gene that had properties of both BAM2 and BAM7. Most genes have a single site where transcription begins, but in this unusual corn BAM gene we found that there are two start sites, one that leads to a longer protein like BAM7 that is targeted to nuclei, and a second one about 1000 nucleotides downstream that leads to a shorter protein like BAM2 that is catalytically active and is targeted to plastids. By examining the presence and absence of these genes in many plants with sequenced genomes we concluded that the dual-function gene probably arose from a single gene fusion event that occurred about 400 million years ago. This single gene then became duplicated at least four times with one member of the pair becoming BAM7-like and the other becoming BAM2-like.
